discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
This configures cucm to send pracks to all 1xx messages via the sip trunk to which this sip profile is assigned.

choices.A: Allow Passthrough of Configured Line Device Caller Information must be enabled.
choices.B: Accept Audio Codec Preferences in Received Offer must be set to On.
choices.C: On the SIP Profile, the configuration parameter SIP Rel1XX Options must be set to Send PRACK for all 1xx Messages.
choices.D: Early Offer for G Clear Calls must be enabled.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If B. is 831[0-10] and that is not typo, only have 2 numbers, so the next correct one will be the C. regardless the numbers are 100.

Selected Answer: C
The range [0-10] is invalid, which makes B incorrect. C is the answer because if there are 100 DNs available, then there are 10 DNs available. The question only states the customer requires 10 DNs, not that the configuration must be exactly for 10 available DNs. So C satisfies both requirements of starting with 8 and providing a set of 10 DNs to park calls.

Selected Answer: C
[0-10] means that for that specific dialed digit, in the sequence, only 0,1 and 0 will match. [0-9] is how you would match 10 digits. Example 8X or 8[0-9]. C is the only viable answer unless as stated previously, B would be correct if [0-9] was used.

Selected Answer: B
B is the best answer assuming they meant [0-9] as [0-10] is not valid

I don't see a correct answer. [0-10] is not a valid range. If this was 831[0-9], then B would be correct. If there is a typo in the question and customer requires a set of 100 DNs (as opposed to 10), then the answer should be C.

questions.question_text: A new Cisco UCM deployment is configured, and now the customer requires a set of 10 DNSs to park the calls starting with 8. The users must use the softkey to park the call. Which configuration must be performed to achieve this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Jonathanm has the actual correct ABCD answers and A. is the correct answer of those options voice class sip-profiles 105 request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify “<sip:1(...)@” “<sip:263411\1@”

comments.content: A is incorrect because it will only match extensions 1000 - 1999, not ALL extensions.
why B? both A and B "generate" 9 digit diversion diversion-header sip-user...

discussion.content:
A. voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify “<sip:1(...)@”
“<sip:263411\1@”
B. voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify “<sip:(...)@”
“<sip:263411\1@”
C. voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion add “<sip:(...)@”
“<sip:263411\1@”
D. voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify “<sip:1(...)@”
“<sip:263411\2@”


Its B.
Impossible to answer because of obvious typos
There is a Typo with this question! The three answers are the same.

questions.question_text: An administrator troubleshoots call failure in a new deployment and finds that the SIP INVITE messages sent to the service provider contain a diversion header with the user's 4-cigit directory number. These 4-digit directory numbers range from 1000 to 9899. The service provider is rejecting the calls because it requires that the diversion header contain 10 digits. Which command on the Cisco Unified Border Element resolves this issue for all users?

choices.D:
voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify ““
choices.C:
voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion add ““
choices.B:
voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify ““
choices.A:
voice class sip-profiles 105
request INVITE sip-header Diversion modify ““

questions.question_text: Some users report having issues dialing some external numbers when traveling to other locations within the company. The company has five locations in five cities in one country and has an egress gateway in each location for TEHO. The configuration has no specific entry stating that the roaming users are using the local gateway, but calls are going out. How is a verification of the call routing in such a specific configuration performed to further identify the problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Pretty sure this question is not worded correctly, but since it discussed users "roaming" between sites the answer is likely A, device Mobility, to ensure they use the correct Device Pool, thus using the correct Standard Local Route Group

choices.D: There are multiple matches for the dialed number, and Cisco UCM is trying to send the call to SEP2834A2824611 rather than Cisco Unified Border Element
choices.A: The calling search space on the calling line/device does not contain the partition of the route pattern
choices.C: A connectivity issue between Cisco UCM and Cisco Unified Border Element prevents Cisco UCM from receiving a response to the OPTIONS it is sending to Cisco Unified Border Element
choices.B: The called party number is not complete because it contains only 7 digits

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It is in the log it is sending it to sepXXXX

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An administrator configured a new SIP trunk between Cisco UCM and Cisco Unified Border Element. Calls that use this new trunk are failing, and debugs from the Cisco Unified Border Element do not show any signaling received from Cisco UCM. The administrator verified that OPTIONS is enabled on the SIP profile configured on the trunk on Cisco UCM. The route pattern matched for this call is correctly configured to send calls to the Cisco Unified Border Element using this new trunk. What is the cause of this failure?
